turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Sorry. These fountain pens are so tricky.

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: Oh! You did that on purpose! I hate you. Go gargle with razor blades!

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I beg your pardon?

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: Take a long walk on a short pier.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Have a nice day.

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: Hey Terry, what is that?  Did Peggy make it up?  I've never seen that on Bandstand.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: What if we're witnessing the end of touch dancing?

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: Terry, slow down.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: Terry! Slow down.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: What, why?

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: There's Peggy with Michael Fitzsimmons.

turns.speaker: TERRY
turns.text: That commie beatnik? What's she doing with him? Wait'll I tell Charlie.

turns.speaker: DOLORES
turns.text: First a nerd and then a weirdo. What a bunch of nose pickers. I'll tell Charlie.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Fine.  ) Grandma, would you teach me how to make strudel?

turns.speaker: ELIZABETH
turns.text: That's a day's work. But if that's what you want, maybe we can do it tomorrow for your birthday.

turns.speaker: ELIZABETH
turns.text: You know, Peggy Sue, your mother said you had a dream that I died.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I wish she hadn't.

turns.speaker: ELIZABETH
turns.text: I'm not afraid. I know exactly when I'm going to die.

turns.speaker: ELIZABETH
turns.text: If you believe it, darling, then I believe. Being young can be just as confusing as being old. The things that happened to me fifty years ago are more on my mind than what happened yesterday.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: But I'm remembering the future.

turns.speaker: ELIZABETH
turns.text: Right now you're just browsing through time. Choose the things you'll be proud of. The things that Last.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: My children make me happy. I miss them so much.  Beth. Scott and Beth.  I'm going to name my daughter after you.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: It was my idea, Grandma. I always wondered what went on at those lodge meetings.

turns.speaker: ELIZABETH
turns.text: He won't tell me, but I've got my suspicions. And I don't want any of that. Don't keep her out late.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: It was Beth's idea.

turns.speaker: MADDY
turns.text: I wish I had the nerve. And the figure.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Beth's boyfriend is playing in the band.

turns.speaker: MADDY
turns.text: It must run in the family.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Don't get your hopes up.

turns.speaker: MADDY
turns.text: Come on, where's your enthusiasm?

turns.speaker: MADDY
turns.text: How come we're your best friends and we had to find out about you and Michael Fitzsimmons from Dolores?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: She's unbelievable. Who needs satellites when we've got Dolores's mouth?

turns.speaker: MADDY
turns.text: Yeah. He's so cool and mysterious.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: He's very interesting. For all his pretending to be a tough guy, he's really got the soul of a poet.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Cool it kids. He's free to see other girls, if he wants.

turns.speaker: MADDY
turns.text: But I always thought that you would marry Charlie, Carol would marry Walter, and I would marry Arthur. We'd all live on the same street and take our kids to the park together and have barbecues every Sunday. It'll spoil everything if you and Charlie break up. That Michael doesn't look like the barbecue type.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I'm not going to marry him. I just went out with him once.  I know! Why don't we go to the movies tonight. Just us girls. It'll be fun.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I was impressed with what you said in English class today.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Gilfond's okay, except he thinks Hemingway's great Literature.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: You don't?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: He's a fisherman! The most overrated writer of the century. I mean, he's the perfect American author  fat, violent, drunk...

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Maybe you're confusing his life with his work.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: A writer's life is his work. Jack Kerouac doesn't have to kill a bull to have something to write about. He's out there feeling, burning... grooving on life!

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: The young man leaned back in his chair. No bulls would die today.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: What're you doing here anyway?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Coffee and a donut.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I thought chicks like you traveled in packs.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Hey, man, I'm a hip chick.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: This is great reefer.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Yeah. I'm surprised. It's really old...  Travels well though.  You know, the world looks a lot better from up here.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: The world is fantastic. It's the ultimate absurd circus. I am shot from a cannon into the energy.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: What are you shooting for?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Maximum intensity. Yeah. I can't wait to get out of here. I'm gonna write. I'm gonna check out of this bourgeois motel. Push myself away from the dinner table and say 'No more JellO for me, Mom.'

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Don't you get along with your parents?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: The only thing my father digs is cold, green money. All my mother cares about is her standing at the country club.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: They care about you. They're just a different generation.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Hey what's with you? I thought you were cool. You rode my bike. You blew some pot.  What's your scene Miss Majorette? You gonna marry Mr. Blue Impala and graze around with all the other sheep for the rest of your life?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I already did that. I want to be a dancer, I want to dance.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: A ray of oneness piercing the solitude. Falling bodies in the ecstasy of flesh. You'll be a chapter in my memoirs of desire.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Is that one of your poems?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: No, I just made that up. Do you want to hear one?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I'd love to.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Okay. Here's a new one. It's called Tenderness.  I couldn't sleep so I thought I'd scream Betrayed by a kiss, sucking pods of bitterness. In the madhouse of Dr. Dread Razor shreds of rat puke fall On my bare arms  I'm sorry. I guess I was trying to impress you.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: That was quite an evening. Bourgeois, phony, decadent, stupid.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I shouldn't have put you through that. It must have been agony. Let's do something.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Five more weeks of school. And ten minutes past graduation I'm gone.  To freedom.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: For everyone.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Now listen, this is the plan. As soon as school is finished we go to Utah and...

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Utah? I thought you'd be going to New York or Paris. What's in Utah?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Rita. I met her last summer. She's cool. You'll really dig her. She's got this great little cabin in the hills, just outside of Provo where she raises chickens. I'll write and the two of you can take care of the chickens to support us.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I can't do that.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Why not? Polygamy's legal in Utah.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I hate chickens.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: But what about the other night? We were like two stars in the same constellation.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Michael, you and I are light years apart. You should go, but not with me.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: But we had heat baby. Passion! Fire! We owe it to ourselves to fuse together.  At least one more time.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: That's a terrific line. You're going to be a wonderful writer.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: You think so?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Yes. We had a glorious night together. One day you'll remember and write about it.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I can dig that. Bittersweet perfection. Dogs of lust on leashes of memory... yeah.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: It's Charlie!

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: What a treat.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Ssh. He's great.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Peggy Sue's still stuck on treble without a cause.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I thought I knew everything about him.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Can we split now?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I can dig you being uptight about Rita and Utah. That's cool. But I've got to warn you about something.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: My father. He's not just the ultimate square. He's a total crook.

turns.speaker: MR. KELCHER
turns.text: Young lady, you're drunk!

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Just a little. I've had a tough day.

turns.speaker: MR. KELCHER
turns.text: I don't see the humor in this. Go to your room immediately. You're grounded.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Grounded? Ha! The story of my life. I don't wanna go to my room. I wanna import Japanese cars. I wanna go to Liverpool and discover the Beatles.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Dad, I never knew you had a sense of humor.

turns.speaker: MR. KELCHER
turns.text: Evelyn, put her to bed.

turns.speaker: MR. KELCHER
turns.text: Thank you.. I accept your apology with the hope that what went on yesterday will never happen again.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: That would be impossible.

turns.speaker: MR. KELCHER
turns.text: You're so young, this is not the time to start acquiring bad habits.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Mom, is there any coffee left?

turns.speaker: MR. KELCHER
turns.text: If all the kids jumped off a bridge, would you do that too?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I think I'm way ahead of them.

turns.speaker: MR. KELCHER
turns.text: Damn that Charlie I

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: It's not Charlie. It's me.

turns.speaker: MR. KELCHER
turns.text: Peggy, let me ask you something.  You're not... expecting are you?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: At my age? Don't be silly.

turns.speaker: MR. KELCHER
turns.text: Thank God for that.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Dad.. it's not a big deal. Didn't you ever stay out all night when you were young?

turns.speaker: MR. KELCHER
turns.text: Yes but I was a boy. And I still had hell to pay.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Calm down. Just listen for a minute.. Please.

turns.speaker: MR. KELCHER
turns.text: All right. But this better be good.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I want to help with the family finances. I want you to buy some stocks. And gold. By 1980 gold is going to be worth eight hundred dollars an ounce. Then you sell.

turns.speaker: MR. KELCHER
turns.text: Do you know how ridiculous you sound? First of all, it's illegal for U.S. citizens to buy gold. And in the second place, the price of gold is regulated by the government.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I think they're going to deregulate it.

turns.speaker: MR. KELCHER
turns.text: That's your problems The more women think, the more trouble they get into.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Oh boy, that's another thing that's going to change. Who's going to think for us? Our husbands? You know, you treat Mom like a maid. It's not entirely your fault. Those were the attitudes in the fifties, and that's the way you raised me. But give Nancy a break, encourage her to go to art school.

turns.speaker: MR. KELCHER
turns.text: I've heard just about enough of this lunacy! Go to your room!

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Listen Dad, please. Buy IBM, buy Polaroid, buy Apple Computer. No, no. Not yet. Buy Xerox!

turns.speaker: MR. KELCHER
turns.text: Evelyn, take her to her room!

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Hi, Dad.

turns.speaker: MR. KELCHER
turns.text: Doing some shopping?

turns.speaker: MR. KELCHER
turns.text: For me?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Open it.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I closed my Christmas club.

turns.speaker: MR. KELCHER
turns.text: Good, you got your money out of that greedy bank.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I wanted to apologize for this morning.

turns.speaker: MR. KELCHER
turns.text: It's hard to believe you're going to be eighteen.  Want an eskimo pie? Or a creamsicle? I'd come home from the store and there's little you running up to me. I'd give you a dime and you'd promise never to grow up.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Quiet today?

turns.speaker: MR. KELCHER
turns.text: This morning was good.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: The hat business is in trouble.

turns.speaker: MR. KELCHER
turns.text: I, that what all that nonsense was about this morning? You're worried about my business?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MR. KELCHER
turns.text: That's very thoughtful, honey. It's just a slump. Things will pick up.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: But when John F. Kennedy's elected President, men'1l stop wearing hats.

turns.speaker: MR. KELCHER
turns.text: Kennedy's a Catholic. He'll never win.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: He'll win.

turns.speaker: MR. KELCHER
turns.text: Richard Nixon's going to be President. Nixon wears hats.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Ta da! Pantyhose! The death of the garter belt! Of course, once they're manufactured they'll look better than this. What do you think?

turns.speaker: MR. KELCHER
turns.text: This is your great invention?  Would you wear those things?

turns.speaker: MR. KELCHER
turns.text: That's all well and good, but we don't have the money to manufacture them.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: You need a partner. There's a friend of mine at school whose father makes seat covers for cars, Mr. Fitzsimmons. I've invited him and his family over for dinner tomorrow night.

turns.speaker: MR. KELCHER
turns.text: You mean to tell me that you invited this Mr. Fitzsimmons over to talk about investing his money in your cockamamie idea?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Wrong, Dad. Your idea.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: How did it go with the pantyhose?

turns.speaker: MR. KELCHER
turns.text: It's the darndest thing. Ed knew what they were immediately. As a matter of fact, he said he's got a product like that in development right now.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Oh no!

turns.speaker: MR. KELCHER
turns.text: Didn't call, them pantyhose, though. What was it, Evelyn?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Oh, you're both so naive.

turns.speaker: MR. KELCHER
turns.text: Look young lady, I grew up through the depression. I fought in the second World War. Six days a week I get up and deal with the public, the bank and the bill collectors. And on the seventh day, when God rests, I don't have to listen to my daughter calling me a fool!

turns.speaker: MRS. KELCHER
turns.text: Jack, take it easy. She gave blood at school today. Maybe she's just a little lightheaded.

turns.speaker: MR. KELCHER
turns.text: This is not giving blood. This is drunk.

turns.speaker: MRS. KELCHER
turns.text: A new car. We can't afford a new car.

turns.speaker: MR. KELCHER
turns.text: Don't worry, it's just a seasonal slump.

turns.speaker: MRS. KELCHER
turns.text: You have four seasons, you have four slumps.

turns.speaker: MR. KELCHER
turns.text: I don't need your charity. I don't need your grandmother's jewelry or your parents money -how could you do that?

turns.speaker: MRS. KELCHER
turns.text: Please don't shout.

turns.speaker: MRS. KELCHER
turns.text: Does everybody have to hear?

turns.speaker: MR. KELCHER
turns.text: I want everybody to hear because I don't have anything to be ashamed of.

turns.speaker: MRS. KELCHER
turns.text: Jack, I was just trying to help.

turns.speaker: MR. KELCHER
turns.text: We'll make it, we'll be fine.

turns.speaker: MR. KELCHER
turns.text: Peggy Sue, watch your mouth.

turns.speaker: MRS. KELCHER
turns.text: Mr. Fitzsimmons is a very prominent man.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Mom!

turns.speaker: MRS. KELCHER
turns.text: The nurse called and said you'd be coming home.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I have a note.

turns.speaker: MRS. KELCHER
turns.text: How do you feel?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I'm excused.

turns.speaker: MRS. KELCHER
turns.text: Why don't you go lie down for a while.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Mom!

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Chanel Number Five. That always reminds me of home.

turns.speaker: MRS. KELCHER
turns.text: Of course, dear. You're home now.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I'm home now.

turns.speaker: MRS. KELCHER
turns.text: My little baby. Don't try to grow up so fast.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Oh Mom, I forgot you were ever so young.

turns.speaker: MRS. KELCHER
turns.text: What happened to your hair? You have such a pretty face. Why are you always trying to cover it up?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Oh. I forgot.

turns.speaker: MRS. KELCHER
turns.text: You're looking pretty chipper this morning.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I'm still here, aren't I? I may as well enjoy myself. I'm going to go to school today.  Dad, I want to apologize for yesterday. The car is a classic. Use it in the best of health.

turns.speaker: MRS. KELCHER
turns.text: When did you start drinking coffee?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Oh.	Ah...recently. All the kids drink it.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Oh yeah. Charlie. How am I going to handle him?

turns.speaker: MRS. KELCHER
turns.text: What's the matter? Did you two have a fight?.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Sort of.

turns.speaker: MRS. KELCHER
turns.text: What about?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: The house payments.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Who was that man?

turns.speaker: MRS. KELCHER
turns.text: It was nobody. Ah... he's a poll, taker. I'm thinking of voting Democrat this year. But don't mention it to your father. How was school today?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: It was great to see everybody again. But it's so boring and regimented. Most of what they teach is useless. The worst thing was lunch.

turns.speaker: MRS. KELCHER
turns.text: Would you get that, dear?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Sure, Mom.  Hello.

turns.speaker: MRS. KELCHER
turns.text: Peggy! What's the matter? Who is it?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: It's Grandma. I can't talk to her now.  I'm sorry, Grandma.

turns.speaker: MRS. KELCHER
turns.text: What happened to you?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I had a dream that Grandma died.

turns.speaker: MRS. KELCHER
turns.text: Well, she is getting on, but she's fine. I told her you weren't feeling well yesterday. She called to find out how you are.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: She did? I love her so much, and I haven't seen her in such a long time. And Grandpa Barney. Is he all, right?

turns.speaker: MRS. KELCHER
turns.text: Yes, he's fine, too. You saw them at Easter.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I'm sorry, Mom. I'll call Grandma back and apologize.

turns.speaker: MRS. KELCHER
turns.text: That's a good girl... I hate to see you so upset.  Tell me, sweetheart. Are you having problems with Charlie? You mentioned something this morning.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I'm confused about a lot of things right now. Charlie's only one of them.

turns.speaker: MRS. KELCHER
turns.text: Is Charlie pressuring you to do things you don't think you should be doing?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: MRS. KELCHER
turns.text: Peggy, do you know what a penis is?  Stay away from it.

turns.speaker: MRS. KELCHER
turns.text: Charlie's downstairs. Why aren't you ready?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: For what?

turns.speaker: MRS. KELCHER
turns.text: Maddy's party.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I don't feel very festive.

turns.speaker: MRS. KELCHER
turns.text: You accepted an invitation, Maddy's one of your best friends, and I baked the Rice Krispie squares.

turns.speaker: MRS. KELCHER
turns.text: Where have you been?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I went for a drive. Up in the hills.

turns.speaker: MRS. KELCHER
turns.text: I'm not the maid!

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Way to go, Mom!

turns.speaker: MRS. KELCHER
turns.text: Would they go over my girdle or under?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Instead of a girdle. And light as a feather.

turns.speaker: MRS. KELCHER
turns.text: Isn't that awfully forward?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: We've got to move fast. This is an idea whose time has come.

turns.speaker: MRS. KELCHER
turns.text: You know, dear, I think the pantyhose is a wonderful idea, but the next time you come up with something, please don't stay out all night. Just tell us. We'll believe you.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Mom, how about a machine that's like your blender, only it slices vegetables, kneads dough, chops meat and even make fresh pasta?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: No, just a friend of mine. I don't think he Likes JellO.

turns.speaker: MRS. KELCHER
turns.text: What does Charlie think about that?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: You know Mom, it's okay to have male friends. Besides, it's over with me and Charlie.

turns.speaker: MRS. KELCHER
turns.text: What? When did it happen? Your dad and I always expected you two to get married.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Yeah, I know Peggy Sue gets married. Case closed. Period. Mom, if you could live your life over again, would you do the same thing? Get married and settle down after high school?

turns.speaker: MRS. KELCHER
turns.text: Sheerotards. Catchy name, isn't it? Like leotards.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: He's a liar! He has no such thing! It's my own fault. I should have had it patented first. He's a crook, damnit.

turns.speaker: NANCY
turns.text: What are you doing?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I'm just happy to see you.

turns.speaker: NANCY
turns.text: Come on! Mom said you were sick. You're never happy to see me.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I'm sorry about that. I really want us to be closer. I have enough unresolved relationships in my... life.

turns.speaker: NANCY
turns.text: Teenagers are weird. And you're the weirdest.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Let's do something together.. Do you want to play Monopoly? Or Careers... Clue... Snakes and Ladders?

turns.speaker: NANCY
turns.text: Okay, what do you want? What dumb favor do you want me to do?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: It's unbelievable. The man never ages.

turns.speaker: NANCY
turns.text: Look at Kenny Rossi. Isn't he dreamy? I wish he'd break up with Arlene. She thinks she's so great.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Don't eat the red ones.

turns.speaker: NANCY
turns.text: Why not? They're my favorite.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: They're bad for you. They cause...red lips.

turns.speaker: NANCY
turns.text: And the butter.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: You know, you two are wonderful parents. I'm really going to try to behave myself.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Mom, sit down for a minute. This is so nice, all of us being together again like this.

turns.speaker: NANCY
turns.text: Can I tell Diane that Peggy Sue got drunk or is that a deep family secret?  Well?

turns.speaker: NANCY
turns.text: You think this'll cheer Dad up?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Of course, he'll love it. You're a terrific artist.

turns.speaker: ROSALIE
turns.text: I remember that dress.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Rosalie Testa!

turns.speaker: ROSALIE
turns.text: I remember when you got that locket, too. You were so excited I think you showed it to the whole school.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: You have an incredible memory.

turns.speaker: ROSALIE
turns.text: What's up?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I think you should give up diving. It's dangerous.

turns.speaker: ROSALIE
turns.text: Don't be silly, I'm the best in the county.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I know you are, but you have to stop. I couldn't tell you before, I didn't know if I should. But you have to stop before you hurt yourself.

turns.speaker: ROSALIE
turns.text: I spend three hours a day practicing. I have trainers, I know what I'm doing.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: But accidents can happen.

turns.speaker: ROSALIE
turns.text: Not to me they don't. I'm going to win the State, then the. Nationals, and then I'm going to the Olympics.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Rosalie, please, listen to me! You have to stop.

turns.speaker: ROSALIE
turns.text: You're sick. You should go to the nurse. I'm going to tell Miss Dennis.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: Are you Peggy Sue Kelcher?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I was once. Richard!? Richard Norvik? I didn't recognize you.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: You look exactly the same.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I just did it for tonight. I don't normally dress like this.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Hello. Nice to meet you. Please call me Peggy. I'm Peggy Bodell now.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: Where's Charlie? I was in town about a year ago and caught one of his commercials. Really made me laugh.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: He's not here. We're getting divorced.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: Gee. I'm sorry to hear that.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: The only time people like Dolores used to pay any attention to me was to laugh at me or insult me. That guy, Doug Snell, who shook my hand when we walked in, he used to call me a foureyed worm.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Well, you showed them. You're rich and famous and successful. And you have a beautiful wife.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: You were always friendly to me. I appreciated that.  You know, this used to be a fantasy of mine.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: What was?

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: Dancing with you.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: You're a sweet man, Richard.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: I guess part of us never really leaves high school.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: You know, I never told anybody this, but I always had a feeling that when you die, before you go to heaven, you get a chance to fly around high school for a while.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Congratulations on the math contest, Richard.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: It really wasn't that difficult.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I have to talk to you. It's very important.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: I'm not doing any tutoring this year. I'm too busy.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: It's not that. Can we meet after school? Please?

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: All right. I'll be in the physics lab. Make it fourthirty. I have a rocket club meeting.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: What a great kite.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: I'm writing a book on kite construction. What did you want to talk about?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I want to ask you a question.  Do you think...time travel is possible?

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: Are you doing some kind of science project?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Sort of.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: Well... in a Newtonian framework, the possibilities were limited, but with the advent of relativity theory, the idea of absolute time can no longer be reasonably affirmed.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: And then, there's Richard's Burrito.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: That's my own theory based on a Mexican food called the burrito. I had it once when my parents took me to Disneyland.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I	know what a burrito is.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: Well, I think time is like a burrito. Sometimes it just folds over on itself and one part touches the other.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: What's inside?

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: You can till it with whatever you want. From illusions to memory, from experience to innocence, from happiness to the entire universes

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: So you think time travel is possible? For people?

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: Absolutely. People, dogs, elephants.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Listen, you've gotta keep this a secret. You can't tell a soul. Promise?

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: Okay. I promise.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: This is serious. Nobody can know. Ah, I've returned from the future. I traveled back here 25 years.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: You probably are crazy. Wait a minute. Is this some kind of joke? I know what you all, think of me.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: You have a blind grandfather. One day you're going to invent a machine that reads books for blind people. I read about it. You're going to be famous. You're going to invent a lot of things.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: How, did you know about my grandfather?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Because I'm telling you the truth. I know what's going to happen. There's going to be test tube babies and heart transplants. And an American named Neil Armstrong is going to walk on the moon. On July 20, 1969.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: Holy Toledo! That's six years ahead of schedule!

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: But when did you leave? Are you here until then? Were you there until now? What direction are you going in? Are you a moving point on an infinite line extending into the past? Can anyone do it?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: I'd be very careful if I were you. You don' t want to fall into the clutches of some madman with plans to manipulate your brain.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: That's why I was getting a divorce..  What I really think is that I had a heart attack at the reunion and died.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: You look pretty good for a corpse.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Come on, Richard, I'm serious.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: You're giving me the creeps.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Am I dead or not?

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: There's one way to find out.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: What're you doing?

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: Confucious says, The way out is through the door. There's a truck. There's your door.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: Okay, you're not dead, but according to every law of science what you say happened to you is impossible.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: What if it's beyond science? What it it's God?

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: You're a molecule in chaos, a discontinuent aberration. Maybe you've just got powers of precognition. Well, maybe you're just out of whack.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I told you, I've already lived my life. I don't know how or why I'm here, but you have to help me get back. I want to get back to my real life!

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: All right, I'll work on it, I'll, do some research. But in the meantime, don't get crazy.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I'm trying. I'll see you tomorrow.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: What if you're not here tomorrow?

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: The way I see it, you have an unparalleled opportunity to become the richest woman in the world.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I'm just not the type. Besides, I want to get out of here.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: But you have a vision. Don't you want to help your parents?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I tried to tell them, but they wouldn't listen to me.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: I'm talking about invention, no investment. I know what people think of me. Mr. Spasmatician. Dick the Square Root. I'll show them. You said I was going to be a millionaire. And you're gonna help!

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Richard, take it easy.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: No offense, but for a person who says she's lived an extra lifetime, you certainly are thick. Money is power.. Money makes people respect you...

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: How come you never ask me any important questions? Don't you wonder if there's going to be a nuclear war? Or a cure for cancer? What about your family? What about people?

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: I'm curious, but I don't want to know. Jeez, I hope you haven't been telling people what's going to happen to them.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Give me some credit, will you?

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: Good. You're discreet. I like that in a partner.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Wbat're you talking about?

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: Look it's very simple. You tell me everything that hasn't been invented yet, and I'll invent it. We'll be partners. Fiftyfifty.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Sixtyforty.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: You're taking advantage of a minor.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: When do we start?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Ah. This is a biggie. Forget sneakers. Running shoes, jogging shoes, tennis shoes. Fifty to two hundred dollars a pair.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: Come on. You can't be serious.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: There are major fortunes to be made here. Leisure time and lifestyles.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: Are you talking ~about exercise? Like gym?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Not for you. Okay, there's lots more.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: You don't have to use pig Latin! Nobody could possibly know what we're talking about.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: All right. These are the choices: microwave ovens, pocket calculators, Walkmans, digital watches and miniature TV's.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Oh.	And huge portable radios. Everything else gets small, but for some reason, portable radios get enormous.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Richard! They don't have any! They never heard of them! Isn't that wonderful?

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: What are you talking about?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: The wave of the future! I've decided on our first fortune! I'll see you later. You just think high tech.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: High tech. I like the sound of that.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Hi, Richard.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: What are you doing?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Jogging. I was running, now I'm jogging.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: That's what you were talking about yesterday? Everybody does that in the future?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Yep. It's going to be a law.  I broke up with Charlie last night.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: That's terrific. You did it. You really changed the course of your destiny.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: It was an unfair fight. He didn't have a chance. I'm taking a real gamble. I loved him for a long, long time.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: Cheer up. Now you can give some other guy a shot. Make it up to him later and buy him a yacht.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: For God's sake, forget the money! I'm going crazy! I'm a walking anachronism. I'm a puddle of deja I'm worried about my kids, Scott must be scared to death, I think my daughter's doing drugs again. I can't have any fun here, I don't have that innocence any more. I can't keep all this in anymore. I feel Like I'm going to explode.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: Look, the best scientific mind in this country is working on your case. May I make a suggestion?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Like what?

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: Suggestion! Hypnotic suggestion! Why didn't I think o~ that before?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: What do you know about hypnosis?

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: Everything. This is perfect. The subconscious mind remembers all. You can give me more information on microchips and then pinpoint what happened at the reunion. Maybe that'll give us a clue on how to get you back.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Look, I'm desperate. I'll try anything. But what if you can't snap me out of it?

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: No offense, but you're pretty out of it now.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: You are completely relaxed. When I count to three, you will open your eyes. One... two... three.  We'll start with something easy. What is your name?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Peggy Sue Kelcher.  Or, Peggy Bodell.  I'm not sure.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: Oh boy. Peggy, what are microchips?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Ah..... they're very tiny... they look like a fingernail made out of an erector set...

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: What will they be made of?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I think it's called silicon. Charlie told me that.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: Silicon is from sand.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: We were lying in the sand. It was my eighteenth birthday... We were so awkward... I would have married him anyway...

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: In the future, will you have to marry a girl before you have sex with her?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: No. The Pill will change all that. Then he wouldn't have blamed me. We were just too young.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: You mean you'll give a girl a pill and she'll want to have sex?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: No. The Pill will be for birth control. But girls do like sex. Maybe not the first time.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: Will you take of f your blouse?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Yes, every day.  Maybe I shouldn't have worn that dress? I told Beth it was a bad idea. That's why they made me Queen.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: No! Yes! I'll be right out, Dad.  Oh shit! Peggy, I'm going to snap you out of it.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I couldn't help it  I loved him.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: One... two... three.  You are now awake.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Richard! You should be ashamed of yourself.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: Me? You went crazy! You started taking your clothes off. I was putting them back on for you.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: That's just perfect isn't it? Did it work? Did you find out why I came back?

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: I think it has something to do with your birthday. You were rambling. I didn't understand the rest.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: God dammit! How'm I gonna got out of here?

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: Hey! Do you have any idea how much those beakers cost? I usually charge for hypnosis.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Oh, go feel up your hamsters! I hear rodents put out.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: What's the matter?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: It's all, gone wrong, nothing's working out.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: Not true.  I think I'm making real progress on the microchip.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: You were meant to. You're one of those fortunate people that good things happen to. I have to get out of here.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: I came to say goodbye.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: Goodbye? Where're you going? What about our partnership? I'm making real progress with the microchip.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: You were meant to  You're one of those fortunate people that good things happen to.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: So are you. You've got a vision.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Vision? I'm a walking anachronism! I've upset my parents. I miss my kids. I could be trapped here forever! And poor Charlie...I got pregnant on my 18th birthday and we had to get married. Tomorrow's my birthday! I've got to get out of here now.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: Did you break up with Charlie?

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: Yeah, yeah. I'm taking a big gamble. I've loved him for a long, long time.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: Okay. Why don't we do something visionary. Change your destiny, Peggy Sue. Change your destiny and marry me.

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: No! No! No! Peggy Sue got married! Case closed. I don't want to marry anybody. Goodbye Richard.

turns.speaker: RICHARD
turns.text: Wait! I'll go with you!

turns.speaker: PEGGY
turns.text: You can't. You're going to be Valedictorian.

turns.speaker: YOLANDER
turns.text: Why are you bothering me about this? Can't you leave it be?
